entry.title: Master Data and Core Logistics Processes in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Master Data and Core Logistics Processes in SAP S/4HANA

Part 1: The Foundation - Material Master Management

Everything in a supply chain, from the smallest screw to the most complex finished product, is represented in SAP as a material. The Material Master is the central repository of information for this data, acting as the single source of truth for all departments.

Chapter 1: Understanding the Material Master

An article, referred to as a

material in SAP, is the fundamental unit representing a good or service that your company buys, sells, produces, stores, or costs. A correctly maintained material master record is essential for structuring processes, ensuring traceability, and maintaining compliance.

Structure of the Material Master

The material master is uniquely structured to serve different business functions through Views. Each view groups data fields relevant to a specific department, ensuring that each team is responsible only for the information that concerns them directly.

View

Responsible Department

Example Data

Basic Data 1 & 2

Planning / Engineering

Description, Base Unit of Measure, Material Group.

Purchasing

Purchasing

Purchasing Group, Purchasing Value Key.

MRP 1, 2, 3 & 4

Production Planning

MRP Type, Lot Size, Safety Stock.

Work Scheduling

Production

Production Supervisor, Production Scheduling Profile.

Storage 1 & 2

Warehouse / Planning

Batch Management, Negative Stocks Allowed.

Accounting 1 & 2

Finance / Controlling

Valuation Class, Standard Price / Moving Average Price.

Sales

Sales & Distribution

Sales Unit, Pricing Group.

 

Data is also maintained at different Organizational Levels:

  • Client: The highest level. Data here (e.g., material description) is valid for the entire organization.
  • Company Code: Data specific to a legal financial entity.
  • Plant: Data specific to a manufacturing or distribution facility.
  • Storage Location: Data specific to a location within a plant where stock is held.

Key Concept: Material Types

The

Material Type is a crucial classification that determines a material's behavior, including which views are available, how it is procured, and how its stock is valuated.

  • FERT (Finished Product): Products manufactured in-house, stored, and sold.
  • HALB (Semi-finished Product): Products manufactured internally or externally that are components of a finished product.
  • ROH (Raw Material): Components purchased externally and used in production.
  • VERP (Packaging Material): Materials used for packaging products.
  • DIEN (Service): Non-stock services that are procured, like consulting or maintenance.
  • NLAG (Non-stock Material): Physical goods that are consumed immediately and not held in inventory, such as office supplies.
  • HAWA (Trading Goods): Products that are purchased and resold without any transformation.

Chapter 2: Creating and Managing Stock Materials

Fiori App: Manage Product Master Data (or MM01 in the GUI)

Creating a material is a structured process. With SAP S/4HANA, this is best done through the intuitive "Manage Product Master Data" Fiori app, which replaces the classic

MM01 transaction.

How-To: Create a Finished Product (FERT)

Let's create a new material for a smart thermostat.

  1. Launch the App: Open the Manage Product Master Data tile from your Fiori Launchpad.
  2. Initial Screen:
    • Click Create.
    • Product Number: Leave blank for internal number assignment.
    • Product Type: Select FERT (Finished Product).
    • Base Unit of Measure: Enter EA (Each).
    • Description: Enter "Smart Thermostat V1".
    • Click OK.
  3. General Information / Basic Data:
    • In the Descriptions section, add descriptions for other languages if needed.
    • In the

Basic Data section, assign the Division (e.g., 01 for Pharmacy, 02 for Cosmetics, or a relevant business unit).

    • In the Groupings section, select the Material Group (e.g., "Assembled Products"). This is key for reporting.
  1. Extend to Other Views: A material is useless without being extended to the plants and sales organizations that will use it.
    • Navigate to the Plants tab.
    • Click Create to add the material to a plant (e.g., Plant 1010).
  2. Fill Plant-Specific Views:
    • MRP 1:
      • MRP Type: Select a relevant type, such as PD (MRP).
      • MRP Controller: Assign the planner responsible for this material (e.g., 001).
      • Lot Size: Define the lot-sizing procedure, for example, EX for lot-for-lot order quantity.
    • MRP 2:
      • Procurement Type: Since this is a FERT, select E (In-house production). If it could be both produced and bought, select
  1. X.
      • Safety Stock: Enter a quantity (e.g., 50) to buffer against demand fluctuations.
    • Work Scheduling:
      • Activate the

Batch Management indicator if this product requires lot tracking.

    • Purchasing (for externally procured goods):
      • Purchasing Group: Assign the buyer responsible (e.g., 001).
      • Plant-Specific Material Status: Set a status to control usability. For a new product, you might set it to

Z1 ("In Creation") to block procurement until the master data is complete and verified.

    • Accounting 1:
      • Valuation Class: This is a critical link to financial accounting. Select a class appropriate for finished goods (e.g., 7920).
      • Price Control: Select S for Standard Price. Enter the standard price of the product.
  1. Save: Click Create at the bottom right. The system will confirm that the product has been created and assign it a number.

Chapter 3: Managing Non-Stock Materials

Fiori App: Manage Product Master Data

Non-stock materials (

NLAG and DIEN) represent goods or services that are not managed in inventory. Their creation process is simpler, involving fewer views. The responsibility for these materials typically lies with Central Purchasing or Finance.

How-To: Create a Service Material (DIEN)

  1. Launch the App and click Create.
  2. Initial Data:
    • Product Type: Select DIEN (Service).
    • Base Unit of Measure: Use a suitable unit like AU (Activity Unit) or EA (Each).
    • Description: "External Consulting Service".
  3. Required Views: The key views for non-stock items are generally Basic Data, Purchasing, and Accounting.
    • General Information: Assign a Material Group (e.g., "Professional Services").
    • Plants Tab -> Purchasing View:
      • Assign the

Purchasing Group.

    • Valuation Areas Tab -> Valuation View:
      • Assign the Valuation Class (e.g., for services). This is crucial for automatic account determination during invoicing.
  1. Save: Click Create. The system will generate a number for your service master.

Chapter 4: Advanced Material Master Functions

Changing the Material Type

GUI Transaction: MMAM

Sometimes, a material's role changes. For instance, a part that was always purchased (ROH) is now going to be produced in-house (HALB). The

MMAM transaction allows you to change the material type to reflect this.

Key Considerations Before Changing:

  • Stock Value: The old and new material types must update to the same G/L account if stock exists.
  • Quantity/Value Updating: The configuration for quantity and value updates must be consistent between the two types in all plants.
  • No Open Documents: It's best practice to ensure there are no open purchase orders or production orders for the material.

Procedure:

  1. Enter transaction

MMAM.

  1. Input the Material number.
  2. Enter the

New material type.

  1. Press Execute. The system performs checks. If all conditions are met, it will confirm the change.

Material Status Management

Customizing Transaction: OMS4

The

Plant-Specific Material Status is a powerful field that controls which business functions a material can be used in. For example, a status can block a material from being purchased, used in production, or sold, while allowing other activities. This is defined in customizing and then assigned to the material in the master record.

How-To: Configure a New Material Status (For Consultants/Key Users)

  1. Access Customizing: Go to transaction OMS4 or navigate via the SPRO menu: Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Settings for Key Fields -> Define Material Statuses.
  2. Create New Entry: Click New Entries.
  3. Define Status:
    • Status: Enter a 2-character key (e.g., Z5).
    • Description: "R&D Pilot / Block Sales".
  4. Set Controls: For each business area (Purchasing, BOMs, MRP, Production, etc.), you can specify the system message behavior:
    • Blank: No message.
    • A: Warning message.
    • B: Error message (blocks the transaction).
    • For our Z5 status, you might set an error (B) for "Sales" functions but leave "Purchasing" and "Production" blank.
  5. Save your new status. It is now available for assignment in the material master.

Flagging Materials for Deletion

GUI Transaction: MM06

In SAP, master data is rarely deleted physically to preserve data integrity and history. Instead, it is

flagged for deletion. This "logical deletion" prevents the material from being used in future transactions. The actual removal is handled by a separate archiving process.

This flagging can be done at different organizational levels, giving you precise control:

  • Client Level: Setting the flag at the highest level marks the material for deletion across all company codes and plants.
  • Plant Level: Setting the flag here marks the material for deletion only within that specific plant and its associated storage locations. The material remains active in other plants.

Procedure:

  1. Enter transaction

MM06.

  1. Enter the

Material number and the Organizational Levels at which you want to set the flag (e.g., only enter a Plant to set the plant-level flag).

  1. Press Enter.
  2. On the next screen, tick the checkbox corresponding to the level you want to flag (e.g., tick the box next to "Plant").
  3. Save. The deletion flag is now set.

Part 2: Batch Management - Ensuring Traceability

For many industries, especially pharmaceuticals, chemicals, and food, tracking groups of products (batches or lots) from raw material to finished good is a legal and quality requirement. SAP's Batch Management functionality is designed to meet this critical need.

Chapter 5: Introduction to Batch Management

A batch is a quantity of material produced during a single manufacturing run under uniform conditions. It serves as the fundamental unit for traceability. A material must be flagged for batch management in its master record (Purchasing or Work Scheduling view) to use this functionality.

Chapter 6: Creating and Managing Batches

Fiori App: Manage Batches

The modern, user-friendly way to handle batches is through the "Manage Batches" Fiori app. It provides a holistic hub for creating, viewing, and managing batch master records, making it a significant improvement over the classic

MSC1N transaction.

Key Advantages of the Fiori App:

  • Intuitive Interface: No need to remember transaction codes.
  • Holistic View: See key details like plant, status, and shelf life on one screen.
  • Data Accuracy: The app prompts for essential data like classification and shelf-life expiration date during creation, ensuring data integrity from the start.

How-To: Create a New Batch in Fiori

  1. Launch the App: Open the Manage Batches tile.
  2. Create: Click the Create button.
  3. Enter Header Data:
    • Material: Enter the material number that is batch-managed.
    • Batch: Leave blank for internal number assignment, or enter a number if external assignment is configured.
    • Plant: Enter the plant where the batch is being created.
    • Shelf Life Expiration Date: Enter the expiry date if relevant.
    • Batch Status: Set the initial status (e.g., Unrestricted or Restricted).
  4. Add Classification: Navigate to the Classification tab to assign a class and enter characteristic values (e.g., potency, color).
  5. Save: Click Create. The batch is now created and ready for use in inventory movements.

Chapter 7: Analyzing Batch Usage

GUI Transaction: MB56

The Batch Where-Used List is a powerful analytical tool for traceability. It allows you to track a batch's journey through your supply chain, either from its origin to the final product or vice-versa.

Analysis Directions:

  • Top-Down (Descendant): Shows where a batch of raw materials or components was used. For example, "Show me all the finished product batches that were made using this specific batch of raw material."
  • Bottom-Up (Ascendant): Shows the origin of a batch. For example, "Show me all the raw material batches that went into making this specific batch of finished product."

Procedure:

  1. Enter transaction MB56.
  2. Enter the

Material, Plant, and Batch number you want to analyze.

  1. Choose the analysis direction: click the

Descendant or Ascendant button.

  1. The system displays a hierarchical tree or list showing the complete usage history of the batch across production orders, deliveries, and material documents.

Part 3: Extending and Customizing Master Data

While SAP S/4HANA provides a vast array of standard fields, businesses often have unique data requirements. Modern SAP allows for flexible enhancements without modifying the core code.

Chapter 8: Enhancing Master Data Records

Business Need: "How can we add our own company-specific fields to the vendor master data?"

In the past, this was done via technical ABAP coding in "user exits" using transactions like

CMOD. This approach was complex and not upgrade-friendly. SAP S/4HANA offers modern, flexible alternatives.

Modern S/4HANA Extensibility Options:

  1. Key User Extensibility (In-App): This is the preferred method for simple enhancements. A trained Key User can add custom fields directly to Fiori apps and their underlying business objects without writing a single line of code. These fields can be used in reports, forms, and other processes.
  2. Developer Extensibility (Side-by-Side or In-App): For more complex logic that cannot be handled by key user tools, developers can build extensions in the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) or use controlled in-app ABAP development. This keeps the core system "clean."
  3. Standard Configuration (SPRO/CBC): Always check standard SAP Customizing first. Often, existing fields or features like partner functions or classification can be used to meet the business requirement without any enhancement.

Instead of the old CMOD process, the modern approach is to analyze the business need and choose the simplest, most standard, and most sustainable extension method available.

Chapter 9: Customizing Logistics Reporting

GUI Transaction: MC19

The

Logistics Information System (LIS) is a framework for collecting, aggregating, and analyzing logistics data. To build flexible reports in LIS, you need to define which data fields (characteristics and key figures) are available for analysis. This is done by managing

Field Catalogs.

A field catalog is a collection of fields from source tables that can be used in your custom information structures and reports.

Procedure for Managing a Field Catalog (For Consultants):

  1. Access Transaction: Enter MC19.
  2. Create/Modify: You can create a new catalog or modify an existing one. To create one, enter a name and description.
  3. Assign to Application: Link your catalog to a logistics application (e.g., 01 for Sales, 02 for Purchasing, or 41 for General Logistics).
  4. Select Fields:
    • Choose whether you are adding

Characteristics (e.g., Material, Plant, Customer) or Key Figures (e.g., Order Quantity, Net Value).

    • A dialog box appears. On the right is a list of source tables for the selected application. Double-click a table to see its fields on the left.
    • Select a field from the left and click

Transfer to add it to your catalog.

  1. Save the field catalog. These fields are now available for use in designing custom LIS reports.

Part 4: Business Case and End-to-End Test Plan

This section integrates the concepts from the guide into a cohesive, real-world business case that you can use as a test plan to practice and solidify your understanding.

Business Case Scenario: "InnovateTech Inc. - Smart Thermostat Launch"

InnovateTech Inc. is launching a new, batch-managed smart thermostat. The project requires careful tracking of R&D and marketing costs, as well as full traceability of the key electronic components.

Test Plan

  1. Configuration (For Key Users/Consultants)
  • 1.1. Define a new Material Status:
    • Goal: Create a status that blocks the new thermostat from being sold but allows procurement of components and pilot production runs.
    • Action: Using transaction OMS4, create a new status Z5 named "R&D Pilot". Set an

Error (B) message for the "Sales" area and leave "Purchasing" and "Production Orders" blank.

  1. Master Data Setup (For End Users/Key Users)
  • 2.1. Create an Internal Order:
    • Goal: Create a cost object to collect all marketing expenses for the launch.
    • Action: Using transaction KO01, create an internal order.
      • Order Type: ORCP (Sales/Marketing Order)
      • Description: "Smart Thermostat V1 Marketing Launch"
      • Assignments Tab: Assign your Company Code and the responsible Marketing Cost Center.
      • Release and Save the order.
  • 2.2. Create Material Masters (Fiori App: Manage Product Master Data):
    • Create the raw material: ROH, "High-Precision Temp Sensor". Activate Batch Management in the Purchasing view.
    • Create the semi-finished good: HALB, "Thermostat Mainboard Assembly". Activate Batch Management.
    • Create the finished product: FERT, "Smart Thermostat V1".
      • In the

Work Scheduling view, activate Batch Management.

      • In the

Purchasing or MRP 1 view, assign the Plant-Specific Material Status Z5 ("R&D Pilot").

  1. Procure-to-Pay (P2P) Flow
  • 3.1. Create Purchase Order for 1,000 "High-Precision Temp Sensors".
  • 3.2. Post Goods Receipt:
    • During the goods receipt (MIGO or Fiori app), the system will prompt for a Batch number. Use the

Manage Batches Fiori app (or the integrated function) to create a new batch for the incoming sensors (e.g., SENSOR_B1).

  1. Plan-to-Produce (P2P) Flow
  • 4.1. Create Production Order to produce 200 "Thermostat Mainboard Assemblies".
  • 4.2. Issue Goods to Production Order: Issue 200 of the "High-Precision Temp Sensors" from batch SENSOR_B1 to the production order.
  • 4.3. Post Goods Receipt from Production: Upon completion, receive the 200 assemblies into stock. The system will prompt you to create a new batch for the HALB (e.g., MAINBOARD_B1).
  1. Quality & Traceability Analysis
  • 5.1. Perform Traceability Check:
    • Goal: Imagine a quality issue was found with the MAINBOARD_B1 batch. We need to know its origin.
    • Action: Go to transaction MB56. Enter the material "Thermostat Mainboard Assembly" and batch MAINBOARD_B1. Perform an Ascendant (bottom-up) analysis. The result should clearly show that batch

SENSOR_B1 of the temperature sensors was used.

  1. Costing and Commercialization
  • 6.1. Post a Vendor Invoice:
    • Goal: A marketing agency sends an invoice for $5,000 for a promotional video.
    • Action: Post the invoice in Financial Accounting. On the expense line item, assign the cost directly to the Internal Order created in step 2.1. This ensures the cost is not lost in the general marketing cost center but is tracked specifically for this project.
  • 6.2. Release the Product for Sale:
    • Goal: R&D is complete. The thermostat is ready for sale.
    • Action: Using the Manage Product Master Data Fiori app (or MM02), change the Plant-Specific Material Status for the "Smart Thermostat V1" from Z5 to a status that allows sales (e.g., Z2 - "Article Valid").
  1. Data Lifecycle Management
  • 7.1. Manage an Obsolete Product:
    • Goal: After three years, the "Smart Thermostat V1" is discontinued and will no longer be produced or sold at the main plant (1010), but it is still sold from a secondary service plant (1020).
    • Action: Using transaction MM06, flag the "Smart Thermostat V1" for deletion, but only at the Plant level for Plant 1010. This makes it obsolete in the main plant while keeping it active for the service plant.
  • 7.2. Archive Data:
    • Goal: Once the product is obsolete everywhere and all financial periods are closed, the data can be archived.
    • Action: The system administrator runs the archiving program (MM71), which will pick up the materials flagged for deletion and remove them from the active database, freeing up system resources while preserving the data in an archive file.

entry.title: Re: 4AN combined with intercompany allocation
entry.content:
Hello @Anja_1 

Thanks for the details.

In S/4HANA Public Cloud, the new Resource-Related Intercompany Billing (scope 4AN) streamlines the creation of billing requests from resource postings, such as time and activity allocations, as well as eligible expense postings. Please note, it does not retrieve results from Universal Allocation-Manage Allocations, SAP Help Universal Allocation

What should you do

Use activity or resource postings as the basis for billable-like time confirmations or activity allocations with intercompany attributes.

If you need to recharge overheads, classify them as a resource-related service activity type with an intercompany rate instead of posting them via Universal Allocation.

Checks

4AN has been activated and configured, including billing profile, material determination, and pricing.

The source postings you intend to bill are actual resource or expense postings with the correct intercompany settings‚Äînot results from secondary allocations.

The new Resource-Related Intercompany Billing (scope 4AN) is activated via the new solution; see KBAs 3565601 and 3622695. SAP Support Portal-3565601 - How to activate the New Resource Related Intercompany Billing solution and SAP Support Portal-3622695 - Unable to find the configuration activity "Activate new resource related intercompany billing

The billing request is created for time recordings and expenses, including resource-related postings. This is stated in SAP Learning, along with the description of the Fiori app for ‚ÄúGenerate Intercompany Billing Request.‚ÄùSAP Learning-Understanding Intercompany Billing for Cross-Company Cost Accounting Posting

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

  6. Advanced Topics

  7. Business Case & Test Plan: Building a Custom Bicycle

    • Phase 3: End-to-End Process Testing (Sales to Production)
  1. Introduction to Variant Configuration

What is Variant Configuration? The Power of 'One'

  1. Variant configuration is designed for manufacturing complex products that are produced specifically for a customer. Think about buying a new car: you choose the engine, the color, the interior, the sound system, and various extras. The manufacturer doesn't have a separate material number for every single possible combination. That would be impossible to manage!
  2. Instead, they use
  3. one configurable material (e.g., "Car Model S") that represents all possible variations. The customer then determines the specific features of the product they want. Variant Configuration is the tool that helps the salesperson or the customer assemble the desired product specifications and, crucially, ensures that the selected combination is valid and can actually be built. The only limits are combinations that are technically impossible or not offered for marketing reasons (for example, you can't combine a basic engine with a premium sports package).

Why Use Variant Configuration in S/4HANA?

  1. In today's market of mass customization, VC is more relevant than ever. It's the backbone of Make-to-Order (MTO) and Configure-to-Order (CTO) strategies. The key benefits are:
  • Drastically Reduced Master Data: You manage one "Super BOM" and one "Super Routing" instead of thousands of individual ones.
  • Guaranteed Producibility: Using built-in rules (dependencies), you prevent customers from ordering impossible combinations.
  • Seamless Process Integration: VC is deeply integrated into the entire S/4HANA landscape, from sales and pricing (SD) to material planning (MRP), production (PP), purchasing (MM), and costing (CO) .
  • Accurate Pricing: Prices can be dynamically calculated based on the selected options using variant conditions.

Key Terminology

  • Configurable Material: A single material (often material type KMAT) that represents all possible variants of a product.
  • Characteristics: The features or options of a product (e.g., COLOR, ENGINE_SIZE, UPHOLSTERY).
  • Characteristic Values: The possible choices for a characteristic (e.g., for COLOR, the values could be 'Red', 'Blue', 'Black').
  • Class: A container (Class Type 300) that groups together all the characteristics that describe a configurable product.
  • Configuration Profile: A link between the configurable material and the variant class. It controls the configuration process.
  • Dependencies: The rules that define the interdependencies between characteristics and control the selection of components and operations (e.g., "If ENGINE_SIZE is 'V8', then TRANSMISSION must be 'Automatic'").
  • Super BOM / Super Routing: A Bill of Material or Routing that contains all possible components and operations for all variants of the product.

  1. Bringing Your Product to Life: Dependencies
  1. Dependencies are the logic engine of Variant Configuration. They describe the relationships between characteristics and control the product structure. You write them using a special syntax in the dependency editor.
  2. Global vs. Local Dependencies:
  • Global: Created centrally (Fiori App "Manage Dependencies" / CU01), given a name, and can be reused across many different objects. This is the recommended approach for maintainability.
  • Local: Created directly on a specific object (e.g., a BOM item) and can only be used there. Use these sparingly.

Dependency Type 1: Preconditions (Hiding Options)

  1. Purpose: A precondition is used to hide a characteristic or a characteristic value until a certain condition is met. It ensures that users are only shown relevant options.
  2. How it Works: The characteristic or value is shown if the condition is true OR if it hasn't been evaluated yet (i.e., not violated).
  3. Example: A special "Tandem Saddle" characteristic should only be visible if the bicycle model is a 'Tandem'.
  • Object: The characteristic TANDEM_SADDLE.
  • Syntax: MODEL EQ 'TANDEM'
  • Result: The TANDEM_SADDLE characteristic will be hidden on the configuration screen. As soon as the user selects 'Tandem' for the
  1. MODEL characteristic, TANDEM_SADDLE will appear.

Dependency Type 2: Selection Conditions (Selecting Parts)

  1. Purpose: This is the most common dependency type. It is assigned to BOM items and routing operations to select them for a specific configuration.
  2. How it Works: The object (BOM item/operation) is selected only if the condition is unambiguously true. If the characteristic has no value yet, the condition is false, and the object is not selected.
  3. Example: We have three different handlebar components in our Super BOM. We need to select the correct one based on the chosen handlebar type.
  • Object: BOM item RACING_HANDLEBAR.
  • Syntax: HANDLEBAR EQ 'RACING'
  • Result: When a user configures the bike and selects 'Racing' for the HANDLEBAR characteristic, the BOM for the production order will contain the component RACING_HANDLEBAR. The other handlebar components, with their own selection conditions (
  1. HANDLEBAR EQ 'MOUNTAIN', etc.), will not be selected.

Dependency Type 3: Actions (Inferring Values - The Simple Way)

  1. Purpose: Actions are used to automatically set a value for a characteristic based on another choice. Values set by an action
  2. cannot be changed by the user.
  3. How it Works: You allocate an action to a characteristic value, a characteristic, or the configuration profile. When the condition is met, it infers the value.
  4. Example: Our racing bikes (MODEL = 'RACING') always come with a leather saddle. We don't want the user to choose this; it should be set automatically.
  • Object: Can be assigned to the configuration profile.
  • Syntax: $SELF.SADDLE = 'LEATHER' IF MODEL = 'RACING'
    • $SELF refers to the object being configured.
  • Result: When the user selects 'Racing' for the model, the value for the SADDLE characteristic is automatically set to 'Leather' and greyed out.

Dependency Type 4: Procedures (Inferring Values - The Powerful Way)

  1. Purpose: Procedures are more powerful than actions. They can also infer values, but they have key advantages: they can overwrite each other, and they can be used for calculations.
  2. Key Differences from Actions:
  • Values set by procedures can be overwritten by the user (if set as a default).
  • Procedures can perform calculations (e.g., calculating the total weight).
  • You can define a processing sequence for multiple procedures to control their execution order.
  1. Example: Calculate the total weight of the bike. The base weight depends on the frame material, and extras add more weight.
  • Object: Assigned to the configuration profile.
  • Syntax (as two separate procedures or one combined):
  • # Procedure 1: Set base weight
  • $SELF.WEIGHT = 10 IF FRAME_MATERIAL = 'ALUMINUM';
  • $SELF.WEIGHT = 14 IF FRAME_MATERIAL = 'STEEL'.
  •  
  • # Procedure 2: Add weight for extras
  • $SELF.WEIGHT = $SELF.WEIGHT + 0.5 IF EXTRAS = 'MUDGUARD';
  • $SELF.WEIGHT = $SELF.WEIGHT + 1.0 IF EXTRAS = 'LUGGAGE_RACK'.
  • Result: The WEIGHT characteristic is automatically calculated and updated as the user makes selections. Since a procedure (not an action) is used, subsequent procedures can modify the value already set by a previous one.

Dependency Type 5: Constraints (Managing Complex Relationships)

  1. Purpose: Constraints are the most advanced dependency type, used for complex scenarios involving dependencies between multiple objects or for intensive consistency checks.
  2. How it Works: Constraints are grouped into "dependency nets" and are not processed in a specific order (they are declarative). They work by defining a consistent state. If the user's choices violate this state, the system flags an inconsistency.
  3. Structure of a Constraint:
  • OBJECTS: Declares all the objects and characteristics involved.
  • CONDITION: The condition under which the constraint is evaluated.
  • RESTRICTIONS: The core logic that must be true for the configuration to be consistent.
  • INFERENCES: Can infer new values (use sparingly for performance reasons).
  1. Example: A company is configuring a computer network. A high-end server (SERVER_TYPE = 'HIGH_END') requires a specific operating system (OS = 'UNIX_PRO').
  • Object: A dependency net assigned to the configuration profile.
  • Syntax:
  • OBJECTS:
  •     S IS_A (300)SERVER.
  • CONDITION:
  •     S.SERVER_TYPE = 'HIGH_END'.
  • RESTRICTIONS:
  •     S.OS = 'UNIX_PRO'.
  • INFERENCES:
  •     S.OS.
  • Result: If a user selects the 'HIGH_END' server type, the constraint will automatically infer the 'UNIX_PRO' operating system. If they try to select a different OS, the system will show an inconsistency error because the RESTRICTION is violated.
  1. Pricing the Variant: Variant Conditions
  1. A key business requirement is to calculate the sales price of a configured product dynamically. A blue bike shouldn't cost the same as a red bike if the red paint is more expensive. This is handled by
  2. Variant Conditions.

How Pricing Works for Configurable Products

  1. You create pricing conditions that reference characteristics. When a specific characteristic value is chosen during configuration, the associated price (surcharge or discount) is added to the total sales price.

How-To: Set up Variant Conditions

  1. Create a Pricing Characteristic: First, create a special characteristic that will be used to link your product options to the pricing condition records. For example, PRICE_LINK. This characteristic does not need to be visible on the configuration screen. Use a procedure to set its value based on the product options selected.
    • Example Procedure:
    • $SELF.PRICE_LINK = 'RED_PAINT' IF BIKE_COLOR = 'RED';
    • $SELF.PRICE_LINK = 'GEAR_21' IF BIKE_GEAR_SYSTEM = '21_SPEED';
  2. Create a Condition Type: In pricing configuration (e.g., using Fiori App "Manage Condition Types"), you'll need a condition type for your variant surcharges, for example, VA00 or a custom copy.
  3. Create the Condition Record:
    • App: SAP Fiori App "Manage Prices - Sales" or SAP GUI transaction VK11.
    • Use your variant condition type (e.g., VA00).
    • Instead of creating a record for a material, you will create it for a Variant.
    • You will see a screen where you can enter the characteristic values that trigger the price. You would enter RED_PAINT and the surcharge amount (e.g., 50 EUR). You would create another entry for GEAR_21 with its surcharge (e.g., 120 EUR).
  4. Link in Configuration Profile: You can allocate variant conditions directly via a dependency to a characteristic value. This links the price to the selection of that specific value.
  1. Result: When a user configures a red, 21-speed bike in a sales order, the system identifies the values RED_PAINT and GEAR_21, finds the corresponding condition records for VA00, and adds the surcharges of 50 EUR and 120 EUR to the base price of the bike.

  1. Let's see how Variant Configuration functions in the real world across the S/4HANA landscape.

Sales & Distribution (SD): Configure-to-Order

  1. This is the most common starting point for a configurable product.
  1. Create Sales Order:
    • App: SAP Fiori App "Create Sales Orders" or SAP GUI transaction VA01.
    • Enter the customer, and then enter your configurable material (
  1. CUSTOM_BIKE) as a line item.
  1. Configuration Screen Appears: As soon as you confirm the line item, the system recognizes the material is configurable and launches the characteristic value assignment screen.
  2. Configure the Product: The user now sees the characteristics (Frame Size, Color, etc.) and selects the desired values from the dropdowns. The dependencies work in the background:
    • Preconditions hide or show options based on choices.
    • Actions and Procedures automatically fill in other characteristic values.
    • Constraints check for consistency.
  3. Confirm Configuration: Once the configuration is complete and consistent, the user returns to the sales order.
  4. Pricing is Calculated: The sales order pricing procedure now executes. The system calculates the net price by taking the base price and adding any variant condition surcharges based on the selected options.
  5. Availability Check (ATP): The system performs an availability check. For configurable materials, this is typically a check against planned supply, as the product does not yet exist in stock.

Production Planning (PP): From Sales Order to Production

  1. The configured sales order is the trigger for planning and production.
  1. MRP Run:
    • App: SAP Fiori App "Schedule MRP Runs".
    • When MRP runs, it sees the individual customer requirement from the sales order for
  1. CUSTOM_BIKE.
    • It creates a planned order specifically for this sales order stock.
  1. BOM Explosion in Planned Order: During the MRP run, the system explodes the Super BOM. However, it only selects the components whose selection conditions match the characteristic values from the sales order configuration. If the customer ordered a red, 21-speed bike, only the FRAME_RED and GEAR_SYSTEM_21 components (and all non-variant parts) will be included as requirements.
  2. Convert Planned Order to Production Order:
    • App: SAP Fiori App "Manage Production Orders".
    • The planner converts the planned order into a production order.
    • The production order will contain the specific list of components and the specific routing operations determined by the configuration. The production team now has the exact recipe to build the custom bike.

Purchasing (MM): Procuring Configurable Components

  1. Variant configuration can also be used in purchasing.
  • Configurable Sub-assembly: Imagine the GEAR_SYSTEM itself is a configurable material procured from a vendor. You can create it with material type HALB (Semi-finished good) and mark it as configurable.
  • BOM Setup: In the Super BOM for CUSTOM_BIKE, instead of having multiple gear system components, you could have one line item for the configurable GEAR_SYSTEM.
  • Configuration Transfer: During the sales order configuration of the bike, the user would also configure the GEAR_SYSTEM.
  • Purchase Requisition: When MRP runs, it will create a purchase requisition for the GEAR_SYSTEM. Crucially, the characteristic values chosen by the customer (e.g., number of speeds, brand) are transferred to the purchase requisition and subsequently to the purchase order. The vendor then knows exactly which variant of the gear system to supply.

Material Variants: Pre-Configured for Speed

  1. What is a Material Variant? For very common combinations of features, it can be inefficient to run through the whole make-to-order process every time. A
  2. material variant is a standard, stockable material (like a FERT) that is linked to a configurable material (KMAT) with a specific, fixed set of characteristic values.
  3. Example: You notice that 60% of your customers order a red, 21-speed bike with a medium frame.
  4. How to Create It:
  1. Create a new material master record (e.g., BIKE-RED-21-M), using a standard material type like FERT.
  2. On the MRP 3 or Basic Data view, link this new material to your KMAT (CUSTOM_BIKE) in the "Configurable material" field.
  3. Click the "Configure Variant" button and permanently assign the values: BIKE_COLOR = 'RED', BIKE_GEAR_SYSTEM = '21_SPEED', etc.
  1. How it's Used: You can produce this material variant to stock, just like any normal product. When a sales order is created, and the customer happens to choose that exact combination, the system can automatically substitute the KMAT with the material variant. If stock is available, it can be delivered immediately, bypassing the entire make-to-order production cycle.

  • Expected Result: The system should automatically set B_BRAKE_SYS to DISC_BRAKE due to the procedure. The user should not be able to change this.
  • Test Case B: Choose any combination (e.g., Large frame, Blue, 18-Speed, with Lights). Go to the result screen and simulate the BOM explosion.
  • Expected Result: The BOM result should show only FRAME-L, PAINT-BLU, GEAR-18S, ACC-LIGHTS, BRAKE-STD, and the common part WHEEL_ASSEMBLY. The routing result should NOT show operation 0040.
  1. Test Step 3.2: Create the Sales Order (VA01 / "Create Sales Orders")
  • Create a new sales order.
  • Enter CUSTOM-BIKE as a line item.
  • The configuration screen appears. Configure the following variant:
    • Frame Size: L
    • Color: RED
    • Gear System: 21S
    • Extras: RACK
  • Expected Result 1: The system automatically selects DISC_BRAKE for the brake system.
  • Expected Result 2: After confirming the configuration, the sales order line item is created. Check the "Configuration" tab on the item detail to see your selections.
  1. Test Step 3.3: Run MRP and Check Results (MD01N / "Schedule MRP Runs")
  • Run MRP for your plant/material.
  • App: "Stock/Requirements List" (MD04).
  • Expected Result: You should see a new planned order for CUSTOM-BIKE that is linked directly to your sales order number. You should also see dependent requirements for the specific components selected: FRAME-L, PAINT-RED, GEAR-21S, BRAKE-DISC, ACC-RACK, and WHEEL_ASSEMBLY.
  1. Test Step 3.4: Convert to Production Order and Analyze
  • Convert the planned order to a production order.
  • Display the production order.
  • Expected Result 1 (Components): Go to the "Components" tab. The component list should exactly match the dependent requirements from the previous step.
  • Expected Result 2 (Operations): Go to the "Operations" tab. The operation list should include the special operation 0040 (Premium Component Surcharge) because you selected the 21-speed gear system.

This concludes the comprehensive guide and test plan. By following these steps, you can successfully implement and validate a complete Variant Configuration scenario in SAP S/4HANA.

 

  1. Advanced Variant Configuration Techniques

Once you've mastered the fundamentals, you can leverage advanced tools within Variant Configuration to handle more complex business requirements, improve performance, and create a more dynamic user experience.

Table of Contents (Updated)

  1. Introduction to Variant Configuration
  2. The Core Framework: Master Data Setup
  3. Bringing Your Product to Life: Dependencies
  4. Pricing the Variant: Variant Conditions
  5. End-to-End Business Process Walkthrough
  6. Advanced Topics (Material Variants, Simulation)
  7. Business Case & Test Plan: Building a Custom Bicycle
  8. Advanced Variant Configuration Techniques
    • Part 1: Advanced Dependencies - Tables & Functions
      • Using Variant Tables for Simplified Logic
      • Using Variant Functions for Complex Calculations
    • Part 2: Designing the User Experience - Interface Design
      • Grouping Characteristics with Organizational Areas
      • Dynamically Controlling the Screen Layout
    • Part 3: The Engineer-to-Order Approach - Order BOMs
      • What is an Order BOM?
      • The Order BOM Process Flow

Part 1: Advanced Dependencies - Tables & Functions

Writing complex logic directly into dependencies with nested IF-THEN-ELSE statements can become difficult to manage. For more complex scenarios, SAP provides two powerful tools: Variant Tables and Variant Functions.

Using Variant Tables for Simplified Logic

A Variant Table is a user-maintained table that stores predefined, valid combinations of characteristic values. Instead of writing a complex dependency to check if, for example, a specific engine, transmission, and country package are compatible, you can simply store all valid combinations in a table. The dependency then just needs to check the table.

Benefits:

  • Simplicity & Maintainability: Business users can often maintain the table entries without needing to understand complex dependency syntax.
  • Performance: Checking a table is generally faster than processing a long, complex dependency.

How-To: Use a Variant Table

  1. Create the Table Structure:
    • App: "Manage Variant Tables" or SAP GUI Transaction CU61.
    • Define the columns of your table. Each column will be a characteristic (e.g., B_FRAME_SIZE, B_GEAR_SYS, B_BRAKE_SYS). Designate one or more as Key fields.
  2. Maintain Table Entries:
    • App: "Manage Variant Table Entries" or SAP GUI Transaction CU60.
    • Fill the table with the allowed combinations. For our bicycle, you could define that the 21S gear system is only valid with DISC_BRAKE for frame sizes M and L.

B_FRAME_SIZE (Key)

B_GEAR_SYS (Key)

B_BRAKE_SYS

M

21S

DISC_BRAKE

L

21S

DISC_BRAKE

S

18S

STD_BRAKE

M

18S

STD_BRAKE

  1. Call the Table in a Dependency:
    • You can use a Procedure or Constraint to call the table.
    • Syntax Example (Procedure): TABLE <table_name> (B_BRAKE_SYS = B_BRAKE_SYS WHERE B_FRAME_SIZE = $SELF.B_FRAME_SIZE, B_GEAR_SYS = $SELF.B_GEAR_SYS)
    • Result: This dependency will look up the frame size and gear system entered by the user in the table and automatically infer the correct brake system.

Using Variant Functions for Complex Calculations

Sometimes, you need to perform a calculation that is too complex for the standard dependency syntax (e.g., complex mathematical formulas, reading other database tables). A Variant Function allows you to call a custom-developed ABAP Function Module from within a dependency.

Benefits:

  • Unlimited Flexibility: You can code virtually any logic you need in ABAP.
  • Centralized Logic: Complex business rules can be encapsulated in a function module and reused.

How-To: Use a Variant Function

  1. Develop a Function Module:
    • Tool: ABAP Development Tools in Eclipse or SAP GUI Transaction SE37.
    • A developer creates a function module. The interface of this function module is specifically designed to pass characteristic values in and out. The values are passed via a structure called CUXC_S_AF_STRUCTURE.
  2. Define the Variant Function:
    • App: "Manage Variant Functions" or SAP GUI Transaction CU65.
    • Create a Variant Function and link it to the ABAP Function Module you just created.
  3. Call the Function in a Dependency:
    • You can call the function from a Procedure.
    • Syntax Example: FUNCTION <variant_function_name> (INPUT1 = $SELF.CHARA, INPUT2 = $SELF.CHARB, OUTPUT1 = $SELF.CHARC)
    • Result: The dependency passes the values of CHARA and CHARB to the ABAP code. The code performs its complex calculation and returns the result into CHARC.

Part 2: Designing the User Experience - Interface Design

A clean, logical, and intuitive configuration screen is crucial for user adoption, especially in customer-facing scenarios. You can control the layout and behavior of the screen using organizational areas and dependencies.

Grouping Characteristics with Organizational Areas

By default, all characteristics assigned to the configuration profile appear in a single long list. Organizational Areas allow you to group related characteristics under specific tabs or headings on the configuration screen.

How-To: Use Organizational Areas

  1. Define Organizational Areas in Customizing:
    • Path (GUI): SPRO -> Cross-Application Components -> Classification System -> Define Organizational Areas.
    • Here, you create the areas for your class type (300), for example: BIKE_SPECS (Technical Specifications), BIKE_AESTHETICS (Colors and Style), BIKE_ACCESSORIES (Optional Extras).
  2. Assign Characteristics to Org. Areas in the Class:
    • App: "Manage Classes" (CL02).
    • Go to the Characteristics tab of your variant class (BIKE_CONFIG_CLASS).
    • For each characteristic, you can now assign one or more organizational areas.
  3. Activate Org. Areas in the Configuration Profile:
    • App: "Manage Configuration Profiles" (CU42).
    • In the profile overview, there is a field for Organizational Areas. You can enter the specific areas you want to be active for this profile (e.g., BIKE_SPECS, BIKE_AESTHETICS).
    • Result: When a user configures the material using this profile, they will see tabs for "Technical Specifications" and "Colors and Style". Characteristics will be neatly organized under the appropriate tab, creating a much better user experience.

Dynamically Controlling the Screen Layout

You can use dependencies to change how characteristics are displayed on the fly, creating a truly dynamic interface. For example, a characteristic can be hidden or made read-only based on other selections.

This is achieved using a Reference Characteristic that points to the special structure SCREEN_DEP.

Example: Make the B_BRAKE_SYS characteristic read-only (not available for input) if the user has selected the premium 21S gear system, because the brake system is determined automatically by a procedure.

  1. Create a Reference Characteristic:
    • Using transaction CT04, create a characteristic called SET_NO_INPUT.
    • On the Basic Data tab, in the "Additional data" section, create the reference.
    • Table: SCREEN_DEP, Field: NO_INPUT.
  2. Create a Procedure:
    • Create a procedure PROC_UI_CONTROL.
    • Syntax: $SELF.SET_NO_INPUT = 'B_BRAKE_SYS' IF $SELF.B_GEAR_SYS = '21S'
  3. Assign the Procedure:
    • Assign this procedure to the configuration profile.
    • Result: As soon as the user selects '21S' for the gear system, the B_BRAKE_SYS field will become greyed out and non-editable, preventing the user from changing a value that was inferred by the system.

Part 3: The Engineer-to-Order Approach - Order BOMs

For some industries, especially industrial machinery or highly specialized projects, even a Super BOM with dependencies isn't flexible enough. The final product might require manual, engineering-driven changes for a specific customer order. This is the domain of the Order BOM.

What is an Order BOM?

An Order BOM is a copy of the configured Super BOM that is saved specifically for one sales order item. Engineers can then manually edit this BOM copy‚Äîadding, deleting, or changing components and quantities‚Äîwithout affecting the master Super BOM. It supports an Engineer-to-Order (ETO) process.

The Order BOM Process Flow

  1. Configuration Profile Setting: To enable this process, you must select "Order BOM" as the process in the configuration profile detail screen.
  2. Sales Order Creation: The process starts the same way. A sales order is created, and the product is configured. This initial configuration determines the baseline BOM.
  3. Launch the Order BOM Workbench:
    • App: "Maintain Order BOM" or SAP GUI Transaction CU51.
    • An engineer or production planner enters the sales order number and item.
    • The system displays the configured BOM structure.
  4. Manual Engineering Changes: The engineer can now:
    • Add a non-standard component required for this specific customer.
    • Delete a component that is not needed.
    • Change the quantity of a component.
    • Configure any multi-level configurable assemblies within the BOM.
  5. Save the Order BOM: The changes are saved. This new BOM is now uniquely linked to the sales order item. MRP, production, and costing will only use this Order BOM, ignoring the master Super BOM for this specific order.

Result: This process provides the ultimate flexibility for one-of-a-kind products, blending the efficiency of variant configuration for the standard part of the order with the manual control needed for the engineered components.
